case_name: Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd. and Musst. Mazirunnessa v. Deputy Commissioner and Collector of Kamrup

facts.text: Two writ petitions Nos. 138 and 139 of 1958 were filed by Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd. of 15-D Sambhunath Pandi Street, Calcutta 9, and Musst. Mazirunnessa, wife of Abdul Gafur of Village Bhoknamari, District Kamrup.

anchor.surface_text: two writ petitions Nos. 138 and 139 of 1958 filed respectively by the two appellants, Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd., of 15-D Sambhunath Pandi Street, Calcutta 9, and Musst. Mazirunnessa, wife of Abdul Gafur of Village Bhoknamari, District Kamrup,

facts.text: The writ petitions challenged the validity of the Assam Fixation of Ceiling on Land Holdings Act I of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: in which they challenged the validity of the Assam Fixation of Ceiling on Land Holdings Act I of 1957  hereafter called the Act .

facts.text: The writ petitions were dismissed by the Assam High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The said writ petitions have been dismissed by the Assam High Court substantially on the ground that since the impugned Act falls within the protection of Art. 31A

facts.text: Assam High Court granted certificates to both appellants to appeal to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Having dismissed the writ petitions principally on this ground the High Court granted certificates to both the appellants to companye to this Court in appeal,

facts.text: Notices under section 5 of the Act were served on both appellants by the respondent Deputy Commissioner and Collector of Kamrup.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 5 of the impugned Act numberices had been served on both the appellants by the respondent Deputy Commissioner and Collector of Kamrup calling upon them to submit a return

facts.text: The notices called upon the appellants to submit a return giving particulars of all their lands and stating their selection of plot or plots not exceeding the limits fixed under s. 4.

anchor.surface_text: calling upon them to submit a return giving the particulars of all their lands in the prescribed form and stating therein their selection of plot or plots of land  number exceeding in the aggregate the limits fixed under s. 4  which they desired to retain under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants contended before the High Court that the Act was invalid and ultra vires and sought quashing of the notice under s. 5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended before the High Court that the impugned Act under which this numberice had been served on them was invalid and ultra vires and so they wanted the numberice issued under s. 5 to be quashed.

facts.text: The Act received assent of the President on December 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the President on December 7, 1956, and was published in the official State Gazette on January 16, 1957.

facts.text: The Act was published in the official State Gazette on January 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and was published in the official State Gazette on January 16, 1957. Subsequently it was amended by the amending Act XVII of 1957 and assent was obtained to the amendment thus made on November 8, 1957.

facts.text: The Act was amended by Act XVII of 1957 and assent obtained on November 8, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently it was amended by the amending Act XVII of 1957 and assent was obtained to the amendment thus made on November 8, 1957.

facts.text: By notification issued by State Government on February 7, 1958, the amended Act came into force on February 15, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification issued by the State Government on February 7, 1958, the amended Act came into force on February 15, 1958.

facts.text: The Act extends to the seven Districts specified in s. 1(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Act extends to the seven Districts specified in s. 1 2 , and from its operation are excepted the lands specified in cls.  a  to  e  of s. 2.

facts.text: Exceptions from the Act include lands held for special cultivation of tea before January 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: These clauses refer to lands belonging to any religious or charitable institution of a public nature, lands held for special cultivation of tea or purposes ancillary thereto and lands exceeding 150 bighas utilised for large scale cultivation of citrus in a companypact block by any person before January 1, 1955,

facts.text: It is common ground that the lands sought to be acquired fall within an estate as defined by Art. 31A(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the lands sought to be acquired fall within an estate as defined by Art. 31A 2 .

facts.text: Assent of the President was obtained for the original Act and the amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have already seen that the assent of the President has been obtained both for the Act as it was originally passed and for the amending Act which subsequently modified some of the provisions of the original Act,

facts.text: The existing law relating to land tenure in Assam is the Assam Land and Revenue Regulation, 1886.

anchor.surface_text: The existing law relating to land tenure is to be found in the provisions of the Assam Land and Revenue Regulations, 1886  Regulation I of 1886 .

facts.text: Petitioners' counsel Mr. Chatterjee conceded that the High Court's view on Art. 31A is correct based on prior Supreme Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed this position is number seriously disputed by Mr. Chatterjee who fairly companyceded that having regard to the decisions of this Court in Thakur Raghubir Singh v. The State of Ajmer  Now Rajasthan  1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 478., Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi v. The State of Bombay 1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 489. and Atma Ram v. The State of Punjab 1959 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 748.

facts.text: Appellants argued that the Act is a colourable piece of legislation aimed at acquiring property for profit.

anchor.surface_text: Faced with this difficulty Mr. Chatterjee attempted to argue that the Act is a companyourable piece of legislation and should be struck down as such.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that there is no substance in the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that there is number substance in the two appeals.

facts.text: Under Assam Land and Revenue Regulation 1886, landholder has permanent, heritable and transferable right of use and occupancy subject to payment of revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 9 a landholder shall have a permanent, heritable and transferable right of use and occupancy in his land subject to the payment of revenue, taxes, cesses and rates from time to time legally assessed or imposed in respect of the land.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is the definition section. It defines land as meaning land which is or may be utilised for agricultural purposes or purposes subservient thereto and includes the sites of buildings appurtenant to such land. Under s. 3 g  the word landholder has the meaning assigned to it in the Assam Land and Revenue Regulation, 1886  Regulation I of 1886 . Landlord under s. 3 h  is a person immediately under whom a tenant holds but does number include the Government and owner under s. 3 i  includes proprietor, land-holder or settlement-holder as defined in s. 3 of the Assam Land and Revenue Regulation I of 1886 but it does number include Government. Section 3 o  defines tenant as a meaning a person who holds land under another person and is, but for a special companytract would be, liable to pay rent for that land to the other person, and includes a person who cultivates the land of another person on companydition of delivering a share of the produce.

arguments.claim: Act is colourable legislation whose pith and substance is to acquire land for resale at profit, not agrarian reform

anchor.surface_text: Faced with this difficulty Mr. Chatterjee attempted to argue that the Act is a colourable piece of legislation and should be struck down as such. His argument is that though ostensibly it purports to be a measure of agrarian reform its principal object and indeed its pith and substance is to acquire the property conferred by its provisions and make profit

court_response_anchor.surface_text: th the tiller or the cultivator. With that object ceiling has been prescribed by s. 4, provisions have been made for the acquisition of excess lands,

arguments.court_reasoning: Pith and substance is agrarian reform via ceiling, acquisition of excess, settlement on tillers at price not exceeding compensation; tenant payment adjusts against their compensation entitlement; eviction under s.18 logical if no settlement; conforms to standard reform pattern

arguments.claim: Colourable legislation doctrine applies only where legislature does indirectly what it cannot do directly (citing precedent)

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of colourable legislation really postulates that legislation attempts to do indirectly what it cannot do directly. In other words, though the letter of the law is within the limits of the powers of the Legislature, in substance the law has transgressed those powers and by doing so it has taken the precaution of concealing its real purpose under the cover of apparently legitimate Vide K. G. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. The State of Orissa  1954 S.C.R. 1

arguments.claim: Object of Act is agrarian reform: ceiling on holdings, acquire excess, settle on tenants/actual cultivators

The whole object of the Act which is writ large in all its provisions is to abolish the intermediaries and leave the lands either with the tiller or the cultivator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landholder rights under Assam Land and Revenue Regulation 1886 s.9 are permanent, heritable, transferable right of use and occupancy; expression 'rights in relation to an estate' has very wide amplitude requiring liberal interpretation; conceded by counsel citing prior SC decisions

holdings.text: The Act is a colourable piece of legislation attack must fail; pith and substance is agrarian reform not acquisition for profit

anchor.surface_text: The Act conforms to the pattern usually followed in that behalf and the attack against its validity on the ground that it is a colourable piece of legislation must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme imposes ceiling s.4, acquires excess s.8-9, settles on tenants s.16 at price not exceeding compensation with adjustment rights; eviction s.18 if no settlement; follows standard agrarian reform to benefit tillers; colourable doctrine requires indirect transgression of legislative powers (citing Gajapati precedent); no profit motive as price capped at compensation

holdings.text: The impugned Act is protected under Art. 31A; challenges under Arts. 14, 19(1)(f) and 31(2) cannot be entertained

anchor.surface_text: Indeed this position is not seriously disputed by Mr. Chatterjee who fairly conceded that having regard to the decisions of this Court in Thakur Raghubir Singh v. The State of Ajmer ... he would not be able to contend that the view taken by the High Court is erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held Act protected by Art. 31A given assent and estate rights; conceded by petitioners' counsel based on binding SC precedents (Raghubir Singh, Ram Narain, Atma Ram)

holdings.text: There is no substance in the two appeals

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that there is no substance in the two appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act validly protected under Art. 31A with Presidential assent, affects rights in estate, legitimate agrarian reform not colourable; writ petitions correctly dismissed
